column11: Review Text

A real credit to the Commonwealth war graves commission whose staff maintain this place beautifully. Contains French and Italian graves as well as Commonwealth service people. Also members of the Indian labour battalions often only known by their English nickname. Was particularly struck by one joint headstone for three young aviators killed on landing who are interred together. A place for quiet reflection for those mostly young people who gave their lives for our freedom
Well maintained! Grass cut and flowers at the graves. Located sweeping up nice place just outside the city. Can be visited at any time of day!

column8: Read up about the Japanese air raid during WW2 to get some context before visiting
column11: Having read about the Japanese raid on Trincomolee and Colombo during WW2 and the loss of over  600 men, 20 ships and one of our aircraft carriers, I really wanted to come and pay my respects at the War Grave Memorial and really enjoyed the experience. The staff that tender the graves are a compliment to the War Grave Commission and do a fantastic job remembering those who gave their lives

column8: Peace and reflection in away from the chaotic roadside
column11: This is a really peaceful place to disappear to and escape the hussle and bussle of Trincomalee roads. Very tranquil setting, which encourages quiet reflection. I went twice. It was fascinating to learn about the different nationalities of those who gave so much, and of how the conflict affected Sri Lanka. A groundskeeper approached me and gave me a little more background info on my second visit. Very knowledgeable and approachable chap. And the place is immaculate, with good bird life. A must visit if you have a spare 30 minutes.

column8: A typical well kept war cemetry.
column11: A tranquil slope leading up from the main road. Very well maintained, I believe by the botanical gardens. Rest room on site. Caretaker/guardian knowledgeable. Numbers of graves date to either the end of the war or just after, so bodies presumably brought back here having been interred elsewhere.

column8: nice place to feel the war
column11: Go Peacefully, stay with respect, and feel the peacefulness. I was able to relate our feelings as Sri Lankans in this place

A touching and very respectful place, which absolutely honours those who gave their lives in this part of the world in WWII. Massive praise goes to the gardeners and caretakers employed indirectly by the CWGC, who do a fantastic job maintaining the plots and headstones, and are also very informative about the people of the various allied-countries, who are buried in the cemetery. Remember to give them a little tip.

today we visited the Cemetery and were really impressed with the way the place was so beautifully kept. We were given an overview of the history of the Cemetery one of the lads who worked there. It is quite a small place and we spent about 45 minutes looking around.A place for quite reflection.
Very well maintained and a tribute to those who made the ultimate sacrifice. A place for quiet reflection.
Beautifully maintained war cemetery. The staff are very informative regarding the graves of WW2 victims.

We visited the Cemetery and were really impressed with the way the place was so beautifully kept. We were given an overview of the history of the Cemetery one of the lads who worked there. It is quite a small place and we spent about 45 minutes looking around.
Interesting for Britisch who colonized and fought the Euroepan wars in the Asian seas. More interesting are the separated  graveyards of the Tamils, Singhalese, Christians and Moslims.

Beautifully maintained Commonwealth war cemetery. Well worth a walk around the 364 headstones. The groundsmen can give some background so worth chatting to them. Really easy walk from the hotels and hostels.

The servicemen who were buried in other cemeterird were transferred to this. There are also graces of servicemen's dependents even buried after the war.It is very beautiful. The servicemen of the British Navy. Sri Lanka governmen
This basically a British military Cemetery. The Cemetery is well maintained. A good place to visit for history lovers.

Just fyi. It is basically a cemetery, with marked gravestones of around 350 commonwealth soldiers, who died in attacks in WW2, by Japanese on navy ships in the local bay. There is no informational boards or anything to read. That said, it's a quiet and very well maintained plot to pay respects.
Did not see anything really special about this venue and child eaisly be given a miss for some more relaxing or scenic spot.

This is the cemetery of the British soldiers dies in the 2nd world war. It is very well maintained so far. You can see the names and some description of the soldiers in each of the tombs. Since this is a cemetery pay some respect and be decent. Good to spend 10mins in here on your way to nilaveli.

Went here to pay respects to people killed in world war 2 met a fascinating man told us all about the history of the place and how it was his dads job before his and passed down to him how his dad and princess Anne planted a tree . The gardens are very very well kept and looked after well

As part of a tour called at War Cemetery to pay our respects to all the brave Men and Women who gave the ultimate sacrifice during World War two. I would urge anyone visiting Trincomalee to call here out of respect.

There are 13 different nationatities buried in this place. Young people who died during WWII and who's now resting in peace there. Not impressive as a monument but at least poignant to see tombs so far away from people's home land.

This site was a bit of a surprise, contains headstones for allied servicemen and servicewomen from several countries as well as merchant seaman. The staff on site do a great job of keeping the place to a high standard and the flowering frangipany frame the place perfectly.
The cemetery is very well kept and beautiful. We wandered around and red the engravings on the grave stones. It’s a nice place for a quick stop.
This war cemetery has been kept very neat and tidy.  A suitable tribute to those war casualties buried there
Both of us were greatly moved. So many young men of about 20 dying so far from home. It's beautifully maintained by a caretaker who's been there 30 years and his father before him.

I visited last week... wow well kept. In the opposite of the war cemetery. One nice and very helpful family selling king coconut water mix with lime and spoon of white sugar... In case if you are there I recommend to try a glass of this mixture... cost you only Rs. 100.00
This cemetery is well maintained and is worth a visit to reflect the many buried who gave their lives to defend the Island and the British Empire

Beautiful place to visit. We took the time to read every grave stone and pay our respects to all these men who died in Sri Lanka in World War 2. As parents we found this very emotional as many died far too young and close to the end of the war.
Pleased we ventured along road from guesthouse to wander through. Beautifully kept garden to walk through in 10 minutes

This commonwealth wargraves commission cemetery in TRINCOMALEE is so beautifully kept. The current caretaker is the son of the previous one and he and his one colleague are doing such a fantastic job. If your a traveller everyone who visits Trinco knows of the Gomesz's pasta hut so if you visit there just walk one minute further out of town and take a look at this cemetery. Spend a few minutes and look at ages on the stones. There are 364 graves and the men and women buried there represent 11 different commonwealth nations. Let us not forget.
Good to know the history behind the involvement of Sri Lanka in the war. Also the Japanese bombed the harbour on Trinco.
Well maintained cemetery if WW2 men who died in Sri Lanka. Many countries represented. Many religions. Very sad.
The cemetery is very well kept and quite personal when compared with the large war graves in Europe. A walk round reading the inscriptions was poignant and interesting and the attendant very helpful.

A small well maintained British Cemetery. There was not much Japanese attacks in this area in WW II. Sadly many of these soldiers and sailors died young near the end of WW II. The caretaker is the son of the first caretaker. He will show you photos and documents related to British Royal visits.
Interesting war graves, couldn't get any story behind the people.  5 New Zealanders identified, possibly from a ship returning from war
Visited this cemetery on the way to Kandy. Very well maintained and serene place. Not much to see except admire the beautiful area.
many war monuments and cemetery including in this war cemetery. this is same seen to Garrison cemetery in kandy
One of the most interesting and well maintained CWWG I have ever visited. Highly recommend chatting to the grounds keeper!
A beautiful peaceful place. Well kept. Very quiet and beautiful. Graves up to the 1960s. Also wives which was nice.

This peaceful cemetary is beautifully kept by the staff. It has 364 graves, and many do not contain bodies having never been recovered. This includes British, French, Dutch forces, but also Muslim and Indian members of the forces - it shows what a truly allied force was out here and 'fought for our futures'. Very moving to walk around the graveyard, any visit pays tribute to the fallen.

Caretaker been here 32 years and his father before him, well informed and helpful. Able to show records and knew history of the graves. Really interesting visit. Recommend to anyone interested in Military history.
Beautifully set along side of Nilaveli  road, and maintained very well and pleasant to visit who devoted their lives for a War
The cemetery is builded like memory for soldiers who died during 2nd war in Trincomalee harbor location.

Popped past on the way to Trinco. Absolutely lovely and the caretaker will show you around. Very proud man whose father also ran the site. He knows all there is to know about the site and more. Ask to see all the record book documentation including letters from visitors. It is quirky and nice to see. A great way to honour those who died in the war, both military and civilian.
Get closer to history and understand a little bit more of WW2 in the East . Well kept and well visited
The cemetery is well maintained and beautifully laid out. The walk around the memorials is quite a somber experience. If you are tracing history this is a place to see.

We stopped at this cemetery on our way Trincomalee.  Being British we had an interest in the area in general and had read about the British and Commonwealth cemetery established here in the 2nd world war.  It was an immaculately kept place, just beautiful to wander around and appreciate the care and respect it is given.  Take the time to stop here, even if only briefly.

The War Cemetery is just north of Trincomalee, it’s not very big but you can’t really miss it, it’s on the right heading north. There are apparently 303 WW2 graves and other Merchant and non war graves. There are flowers, cacti, and other type of plants in between and around the graves and they really look well with differing colours, the site is really very well looked after. I spoke with a caretaker of the site he told me a lot of the graves where men from an aircraft carrier that was sunk by Japanese forces out of Batticaloa. This is an excerpt from amazinglanka.com “The Trincomalee cemetery was originally the Combined Services Cemetery, but was taken over by the Admiralty from the military authorities in April 1948 for use as a permanent naval cemetery. On the withdrawal of United Kingdom Forces from Ceylon it became the property of the Ceylon Government is today maintained by the Ministry of Defense on behalf of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission. The cemetery records 303 world war II causalities. Save for a few post-war and non-war graves it is purely a war cemetery, and service war graves were transferred to it from Trincomalee (St. Mary) Churchyard; Trincomalee (St. Stephen’s) Cemetery, Kottadi Cemetery, Jaffna; and Vavuiyna Combined Cemetery. A special memorial commemorates a naval man buried in Trincomalee (St. Stephen’s) Cemetery whose grave could not be found. The non-war graves are those of men of the Merchant Navy whose death was not due to war service, and of civilians, of whom some were employees of the Admiralty; while the post-war graves were dependents of servicemen, civilian employees of the Admiralty and dependents of such employees.” It’s worth a visit just to remember.

There is something very sobering about wandering around a War Cemetery and reading the headstones.  All those lost young men, some as young and 18, gone before their lives had started. As a mother of sons, I found the whole experience very moving and a reminder of why we must avoid future wars and why we must learn from our past. The cemetery is set in beautiful garden like grounds and is very well kept.  It is a place where these mostly British soldiers and sailors can rest in peace and not be forgotten.  It is one of the six Commonwealth war cemeteries in Sri Lanka, and is maintained by Sri Lankan Ministry of Defense on behalf of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.
This is only a small cemetery that pays its respects to the British forces who served here during WWII. It is well maintained & is worth a visit if you are interested in war time history.
Very close to the main hotels and restaurants in uppuveli. It is reflecting the sadness of a war. They are rest in peace in unknown soil

This is a beautifully kept Commonwealth war grave Cemetery. It gave a wonderful insight into the war and how it affected the various nationalities involved. It is also a lovely place to sit and comtemplate!
Its nothing special at this cementry unless you have some ralatives who died at the second world war and have buried there.

I was particularly privileged to receive a personal tour of this superbly kept Commonwealth War Cemetery. The caretaker, Raja (?), has followed in his father’s footsteps and in the finest traditions of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in presenting a splendid resting place. Please go and see and pay your respects to the fallen.
Less than 1 km from uppuveli beach. Nice place to memorize the world history. Honor to pay respect who rest in peace here.
An honour to pay my respects to the people of many nations who fought to make Sri lanka what it is today.
That is a 2nd World war cemetery on the war time many Dutch ,British and sri lankan peoples also died war time now that bodys barried in that cemetery for visit anyone .

Very well maintained WWII cemetery, very beautiful flowers. Well worth a visit to pay your respects to those lost during the war. British, Dutch, Indian and Sri Lankan graces, amongst other allies. Cemetery is small and only needs 15-20 minutes.

Lovely little cemetery. As usual with all military cemeteries looked after by the War Commission, this one was well maintained. Interesting information on gravestones. So many nationalities represented

Firstly, it is not a tourist attraction as such- it is a cemetery, so those who have no interest in WW2 history or a some personal link may choose not to go instead of giving silly reviews. It is a very well maintained place, and people who think the WW2 was only about European or American forces should go and see how Indians and Sri Lankans of all religions also made sacrifices and that they are commemorated here with the same dignity and respect that is accorded to RAF, RN and NZ Navy personnel. The headstones of every religion are here, with suitable inscriptions. A quite place, full of resonance for WW2 students.
Just a beautifully maintained cemetary of the British military  soldiers of the British Empire who were killed or died during World War II.

We find this place quite by accident, and stopped to have a look. Mr Vasantharajah was kind enough to show us around at such short notice. He is very knowledgable about those buried in the cemetery, and about WW2,  and made our visit very interesting. The cemetery is wellmaintained and kept in immaculate condition. He is very proud to show photos of Princess Anne who has visited the cemetery and takes great pleasure in showing you his letters of commendation from a variety of dignitaries. A worthwhile experience.

We took lots of photographs here which we will forward.  The man in a charge keeps this cemetery well maintained and looks after it with such care an dedication it moves you to tears.  A memorable and moving visit.
For us it has no memory. Of course for the Sri Lankan people it’s an important place. If you don’t go you won’t miss out on anything.

Beautifully kept.  One of the gardeners was on hand to provide a lot of information via our guide.  My partner, being ex merchant navy, was very interested and has purchased a book to learn more about the Japanese attack.
This war cemetery has graves of seamen from many countries.  The port of Trincomalee was used by British  war ships during WW11.
As all Commonwealth War Grave Cemeteries, this is beautifully kept and should serve as a reminder to all that life is great, war is grim

The caretakers obviously take great pride and care in their job. We had a personal reason for visiting, as a relative is buried there - otherwise we may not have visited Trincomalee on our holiday. The cemetery is beautifully maintained - the headstones are cared for, each with its own shrub and the grass is green and lush despite the baking temperatures. The caretaker assisted us in finding our relative's headstone, though it's not a huge cemetery so no need to have a grave reference location when you attend.

Well kept in our own British style. So many men were lost in ships around here.  There are a few French graves, plus Hindu's, a Burmese and I think one Muslim.  The records are now kept elsewhere but there is a phone number in the register box to phone if you want to see it.
Located on Trincomalee Nilaveli main road. Representing the second world war. Maintaing it carefully. Nice place to visit when traveling to nilaveli

We walked here as out hotel wasn’t that far away. The cemetery is so well kept, the caretaker came out of his home to speak to us, he certainly takes a pride in his work and his knowledge of the different graves and ages of the dead. Worth a visit.

Recently visited the cemetery with two of my clients from England. The place brought almost brought sad memories to them. Is one of the many cemeteries dedicated to World War II foreign armies in Sri Lanka. Well maintained place which  would bring peace to your mind.

A beautifully kept and respectfully looked after WW2 cemetary, a place to reflect what we owe to so many young men who came from around the world, and so many who were laid to rest in so many far away lands.
We did not actually walk around the cemetery as had a long journey to do but our guide explained that it was for the soldiers etc who lost their lives in the long struggle which cost Sri Lanka dear.

While we bicycled to the Golden temple, we stopped by at this cemetery.  Very well maintained .  The man who takes care of it told us that he inherited the job from his father.  He lives next door and has excellent information sheet in English.  Reading epitaphs made me cry a bit until I saw 'Curry anything'.
There are some very interesting headstones and some unusual histories. Well worth the trip. Reasonably easy to find

Tucked away on highway A6 this cemetery is significant for many reasons. A visit to this place will serve to remind us all about the incredible sacrifices made by so many in World War Two. Combine with a read on the battle of Ceylon as this provides some perspective. Take some quiet time out to walk and reflect through this cemetery.
Similar to the one in Kandy, honours those fallen in WW II.  Well maintained and picturesque, it's easy to miss it if you don't keep a sharp look out.
The cemetery is well maintained and a place to see if you travel around in Trincomalee. This is situated next to the Trincomalee - Nilaweli main road.

My son was amendment to See this site. It was not far from hotel Tru Blue and well maintained by the care taker. A site to pay Respect for the marines who perished in the war. Short time will do as it’s not big site.

Located on the main road in Uppuveli. This as all Commonwealth War Cemeteries is peaceful and very well maintained containing the graves of a number of nationalities including Sri Lankans and Indians. A must see to remember the men and women who sacrificed their lives for us.
Well kept cemetery, sad pleasant little cemetery. But not worth going out of your way to see. Closeby to Nilaweli Beach, also a very very quiet little area. You can bus it their if you like.

Before our visit I was unaware of the conflict that took place in the bay. But after walking around the cemetery and seeing the names of all of the young men and women that perished during the attack and the names of the ships that were anchored off shore I have researched the incident , what an awful incident that is all but forgotten.

While srilanka was ruled by the British empire, srilankan soldiers fought in the 2nd world war. This cemetery is a memorial cemetery for the soldiers who gave their lives valiantly in the front lines of war. It's a must visit historical site in Trincomalee. The place is well maintained. It's about 20 minutes drive from the city centre.

It's easy to miss this little cemetery on the road from Nilaveli to Trincomalee town but it is  an intriguing place to visit with its tombstones commemorating many who died in World War II.Beautifully maintained, the cemetery pays tribute not only to British soldiers and sailors but also to Indians, Sri Lankans, Canadians and even the French who helped to fight the war.The tombstones are intriguing because they reflect symbols from many religions and even incorporate inscriptions in Arabic.
This war cemetery was located near the Nilaveli main road in uppuveli. Well maintained place. If you are really interesting about the world history perfect place to visit.
It is well maintained and located on the main road. A grim reminder of the losses during world war and many who are buried there are in their early twenties or even less.
This place remembers the british and local sodiers who defended the island against the japanese attackes.  Well maintained, and a place to ponder

Very well kept cemetery, it was very moving walking around and understand the sacrifice of so many of different nationalities, religions and all ages. The staff here have done a wonderful job and credit to people who are laid to rest here.
Courteous attendants and a mindful place to visit. Only small but well looked after. Easy walk from Uppuveli.

A beautiful and tiny cemetery in Trincomalee  which is absolute worth a visit; there are a lot of young people burried including 6 Dutch ones. This cemetery is well preserved, every stone has the same shape and colour, beautiful plants and flowers. I found this a very peaceful cemetery; the people burried here deserve all the respect.
A beautiful and peaceful place. Extremely well looked after. Easy to locate and visit. Sad but important.

This is a quiet and reflective place with graves of servicemen and women who died in and around Trinco during and after the Second World War. So many of these people were in their teens and twenties. The area is beautifully maintained.
This is a peaceful cemetery which was nice to visit at dusk when it was a bit cooler. The place is beautifully maintained and some of the words on the gravestones are lovely.

The war cemetery is well kept. It is on the side of the main road accessed by metal gate. When we arrived it was late morning and two gardeners were preparing the cemetery for a visit from the Commonwealth commission. The cemetery caretaker showed us around and explained to us about the different graves, who was buried there and what the different shaped gravestones meant. There is a tree there planted my princess Anne when she visited.

Beautiful and well kept Commonwealth War Grave for those of many allied nations who gave their lives during the Second World War and afterwards. Very well kept and humbling. A credit to the steward of the cemetery and the great work done by the Commission more generally to preserve the memory who gave their lives for freedom.
This first time cemetery neer alex Garden is the Second World War memory asymmetry is looking very beautiful this guys are keeping it very clean most of to
Nice historical location to view WW II grave sites of soldiers. Well maintained place. best to visit in the evening time.

The cemetery is beautifully maintained. Lovely marked gates at the front and the graves are on the hillside looking down towards the road. So sad to read the inscriptions of those that died - all so young and so long ago. It was so nice to see that they aren't forgotten and respected today in the care shown to their graves. This is a must visit for any person.
This Cemetery is well maintained and very clean. The Garden is also maintained very well and I felt it is a great tribute for those who sacrificed their lives
Beautifully maintained with a resident, very knowledgable caretaker who could locate N.Z. Graves for us. Well worth a short stop.
We visited this very well kept war cemetery and learnt a lot about Sri Lankan involvement in the war.  The caretaker and his family were lovely.
Cemetery of Second World War soldiers. Not a crowded place. It is said that the families of the dead soldiers are the visitors. There is a sentimental value in this place.

We had links to Trincomalee Harbour from before the second world war and my father was stationed there during WW2.  A visit to the cemetery was high on our agenda and we were not disappointed.  It is beautifully maintained by a young gentleman whose father was the custodian before him.  He made us very welcome, gave us an interesting tour and insisted we signed the visitor book, which had some illustrious names...

The British know how to care for the cemeteries of its war dead. It is a peaceful site. Reading the tombstones reveals once again the waste of life brought by war and the personal tragedies of those killed and their families.

This is a lovely war cemetery.  Well maintained.  The gravestones are interesting in that they each have a carved 'medallion' indicating which branch of the service the person was in.  There are also a couple of unknown soldier graves.

The Commonwealth War Cemetery is in Uppuveli a few kilometres north of Trincomalee. Expect to pay 400 rupees for a tuk-tuk from the south/centre of Trincomalee.The cemetery is beautifully maintained and holds the graves of 362 military personnel. A visit is a moving and sombre experience. For me the most moving moment was finding the grave of a young man who died on the day I was born. There are many nationalities buried together here including British, Indians, Italians, Australians, Canadians, Dutch and Burmese. Those buried here include those killed in the Japanese air raid on Trincomalee in April 1942. A visit is strongly recommended.
Immaculately kept small cemetery, well cited close to the city centre. Mainly WW2 graves but also post war graves
A small 2nd World War cemetery, peaceful and well tended, although of little interest to non-British folks.

This is a well kept war cemetery on the Nilaveli road within easy walking distance of the Trinco Blu hotel. There is a visitor’s book that the caretaker holds and who also keeps the site so beautifully. We were very pleasantly surprised to see how many visitors had already signed the book in 2017. Most of those buried here were British Royal or Merchant Navy servicemen but there were other nationalities and faiths and, as it should be, there was no discrimination on the location a grave by nationality, faith or rank. The terrible tragedy of war is brought home by the age of many of those buried here, most were in their late teens and early twenties. Some headstones had inscriptions from parents who had lost their only son - truly heartrending to read.

Moving and very poignant visit to Trincomolee War Cemetery. Immaculate kept 2nd World War graves Very moving to see so many Commonwealth countries young men gave up their life's for the price of our freedom
The war cemetery is beautifully looked after. It contains memorial headstones of all those who laid down their lives for king and country in the First and Second World Wars

Trincomalee World War Two Cemetery On the road to Nilaveli just outside Trincomalee on the right hand side of the main road is a beautifully maintained cemetery which contains the graves of the many service people killed whilst defending Trincomalee from the Japanese. Most were so very young and so very far from home. There is such a strong feeling here that my wife was reduced to tears. Lots were British sailors, soldiers, and nurses but there is also a sprinkling of other Nationals who assisted in various ways and gave the ultimate sacrifice. It is a must visit if you are in the area. The British War Graves Commission pay for its upkeep.

This is a small but elegant cemetary. well maintained head stones and pristine flower beds mark each burial. One cannot help but be moved by the dedications and epitaphs on the graves, many of which were for Naval personnel in their early twenties. A few of the dedications indicated that they were for people who lost their lives during the Japanese air raid on 9th April 1942. It was heart warming to see that many different faiths (Christian, Hindu, Muslim) laid side by side and were equally honoured for their sacrifice.
More than the cemetry, it is the shop opposite to the cemetry that attracts the visitors as they sell the cool king coconut. The Cemetry is very small but it is very clean and well preserved.
This closes now days . U cannot enter in side. U can hardly spend 10 min by watching them outside It is just on the road there are no special place

A well maintained cemetery. We walked around the tombstones and were heartbroken to see the lives that were lost as a result of the war. A good place to spend some time and discuss the futility of war.

Our driver drew our attention to this cemetery in passing on our way to Nilaveli and I prevailed on him to return the following day as this was the 11th Nov. That this was an auspicious date was lost on him at first. This cemetery is beautifully kept and anyone who has a relative here should know that the guys are being well cared for.  I met the man in charge of the upkeep and thanked him for his obvious devotion to the job. There are servicemen here from all over the commonwealth - Canada, Africa and NZ are represented and almost everywhere in between including several Dutch sailors. Next door is a school and as you walk around the graves you can hear the children laughing and playing without a care in the world which is just as it should be.
Stopped had a little look round was very well kept  men there tiding   Nice to see  looked after on a nice place to lay to rest and in peace
Most of the tombstones show how young the men were who perished in the war...what a waste of life. The Cemetry is well maintained though

First came across the cemetery in 2002, when it stood out all exposed on the Nilaveli - Trincomalee road. This time, although we were staying just round the corner at Cinnamon  Trinco blu we set off to visit again we actually drove past three times before finding it as shrubbery and trees have grown around it, concealing it from either side. However the experience is just as moving emotionally and having visited many of the Commonwealth war graves in France, the graveyard is just as well maintained by the current caretaker who took over from his father. A must visit location if in the Trincomalee area

We just stumbled over this while out exploring.  I try to visit Commonwealth War Cemeteries wherever I go so thus was a fortunate find. Like most Commonwealth Cemeteries this is well maintained and cared for. The caretaker is a lovely man who will help you find particular graves or nationalities. It is a fitting resting place for our fallen. Lest We Forget.

This is very close to the Cinnamon Blu hotel and its good to stop over and visit this cemetery. there is a caretaker and he will help you out with any questions you would have about the deceased. The garden had lots and lots of butterflies. (that time of the year, I guess) Please remember to sign on the guest book with your thoughts.

I cried... I never cry in graveyards... Learn about Trincomalee before you come here. Get an understanding then come see it for yourself. It's rather small but enough to hit you in the face... the caretaker is unreal. His knowledge is above the rest and we have him 500R for the tour and wasn't disappointed at all...
Really nice to see now well kept this cemetery is. Definitely worth a visit if you are interested in colonial and military history.

We stopped and got down the tuk tuk when we were on the way to the city.Glad we stopped and spent few minutes reading the tombstone inscriptions.It was touching and sad to see the age and the message from loved ones. Well maintained place.

Well organized & well maintained. The person who incharged is very friendly & informative. Several times I've been there with my clients. Also there are another 3 world war cemeteries around the island. One in kandy & two in colombo. Kandy cemetery is very beautiful. Worth watching.
So sad to see so many long men give their lifes but nice to see it so well looked after.  We were nicely greeted and invited to sign the visitors book.

We paid our second visit to the cemetery and were welcomed by the curator whose knowledge of the numbers and nationalities of the occupants is impressive. He pointed out the tree planted by Princess Anne on her visit 20 years ago, and was kind enough to show me some photographs of that occasion, when his father was curator (for 27 years in all). The last time we visited the ground was dry and the grass parched; this time it was lush and green and beautifully tended. A credit to the curator.
Five minutes walk from Trinco Blu and well worth a visit. The caretaker showed us around - his father was the caretaker before him - and it's beautifully cared for and rather humbling.

The cemetery is about 5-10 minutes walk from the turnoff for both the Trinco Blu and the Amaranthe hotels.  It's from World War 2 and commemorates the Christian, Buddhist, Hindu and Muslim soldiers who died in the war. If you are looking for a specific headstone then you could either look it up beforehand on the Commonwealth War Graves Commmission website or talk to the wonderful caretaker there, Mr Vasantha Raja, who has known the place all his life and followed his fathers footsteps into the role. He will show you around the small site and point out some key plots. He and colleagues also maintain a fantastic selection of plants around the headstones. Don't miss it.

Located a few minutes outside Trincomalee, and a couple of minutes from Cinnamon Blu, the cemetery is beautifully maintained. It is remarkably tranquil given its proximity to the road, giving a sense of reflection and remembrance. The grounds are relatively small, but are perfectly maintained by the son of the original groundsman. He is proud of his work, including. It is free to visit, however we felt a donation was the right thing to do.

I know bad pun, but this place is a gem if you like war history and the caretaker is a really nice chap who tells you about the graves. It's really well kept, most graves are British but some Sri Lankans, New Zealanders, British,I was keen to see the graves of the British fallen, very moving.

The age of those buried here seems to average around twenty. The whole place is well maintained, orderly and as with all official war graves there is a guide book present to help you find out more. There are Christian, Hindu, Jewish and Muslim graves. Indian labourers lie alongside Royal Marine Commandos. War knows no religion or caste. All are equal in death. We didn't find sailors from the ship we were looking for (HMS Cornwall sunk in these parts, my wife's Grandfather was on board and recovered in Tricomolee we wondered if he had ship mates here we should pay respects to on his behalf) but we found hundreds of stories that deserve to be told. We found a painful and quiet place that doesn't glorify war but shows the reality of it.

A beautifully kept cemetery to have a look around.  The caretaker was there and showed us some information and letters etc relating to the cemetery.  We enjoyed meeting him and couldn't help but be impressed by his pride in looking after this lovely place of remembrance. Well worth stopping to visit.

Before going we didn't expect a lot, but it was overwhelming. Very well kept, very decent, very respectfully cemetery for those who left their lives in the Second World War in Sri Lanka, Ceylon at those times. I wish a cemetery like this for al the people who died during the Sri Lankan civil war, especially for them, 40.000 refugees, who died in May 2010 during the final bombings on the small beach-strip of Mulaitivu, which was actually a safe non-fire zone.

Well maintained and taken care of. It appeared closed when we went there, but then we opened the gate and approached what looked like the caretaker's house and asked his permission. he then got his son to open the main gate and let us in. You can park on the main road and go in. It is sad that not a lot people visit this beautiful place.
We stopped by here and were moved by the small tour we were taken on the caretaker. Well worth the visit.

We visited in the afternoon, after a short walk from our hotel. When we entered through the gates we were greeted by the caretaker, who showed us around and sat down with us and told us about the cementery and the soldiers whose remains are buried in the graves. It was very moving to read the comments left by the families on the tomb stones. The cementery is well taken care of and definitely worth a visit.

This is the first cemetery where I saw tombstones of Hindus,Muslims ,Sikhs and Christians all in one place. They were all soldiers who lost,mostly their young lives, in the second world war. The Cemetery is well maintained with loving care by planting flowers on each tombstone and keeping it neat and clean.

Located off the main road between Trincomalee and Nilaveli this war cemetery is a beautifully maintained tribute to those foreign troops who fell in Sri Lanka during World War Two.  Given the harsh climatic conditions of this area it is nothing short of amazing how the landscaping is kept in the manicured state it is in.  Highly recommended.

Do visit if you are in the area - it is immaculate & moving. How to find it: From the main A6 road, just south of the town of Trincomalee, turn left onto the North East Coast Road, also known as the Nilaveli Road. The cemetery is approximately 6 kilometres along this road on the right (eastern) side.

Usually war cemeteries can be a bit grim, but here all the plants between the graves make it a peaceful place. We almost thought the stones were new but the caretaker told us they are cleaned every 2-3 month. All these mostly very young man...

I always visit war cemetery's when I travel - out of respect and because maybe families cant visit their lost ones at these locations. This is perhaps one of the best presented and cared for cemetery's I've seen. The grounds men take great care and are so enthusiastic to speak to you about the grave and tell you the history.

I intednd to dive the wreck HMS Hermes.  Feli the Tec dive instructor mentioned that three bodies of soldiers of the wreck hermes are buried here.  I found them. I entered my name in the visitors book.

We stopped to pay our respects on our way to Pidgeon Island.It was a very sad and moving experience.All those young men so far from their homes and families.Mostly the same age as our own kids.Beautiful sunny place,the cemetary keeper.Mr.Vasautharaja is doing a very good job of maintaining the lovely gardens and each grave has a flowering shrub.He showed his collection of photos some from his father's time as grave keeper .We saw the list of their parents names and addresses,even their middle names,we thought of those parents and their awful loss.

Our driver stopped here on the way to Trincomalee which we were visiting in order to find an ATM. It was unexpected but well worth a visit. A well looked after cemetery, we met one of the gardeners. Every grave had a different flowering shrub. So many young sailors are buried here, many only 18.
Very easy to find on the main road in Uppuweli. This is  beautifully maintained by the onsite caretaker who also provided us with a wealth of knowledge. Highly recommend a visit.
This was a well manicured cemetery that had the graves of world war ii commonwealth soldiers who died in Sri Lanka.
This is one of the well maintain cemeteries that I have seen . the landscaping tells everything about it A place that holds important part of history in sri lanka
Interesting to walk around, very clean and well kept. There are many gravestones for Air/Navel and Army personnel from all over the commonwealth.
Like all of the war cemetery's we visited in Sri Lanka it is well tended clean and tidy  and thankfully does not have to many graves.
What ever your faith or belief  it is well worth walking around this place it is so well kept & so sad to see so many young lives wasted.
This small well maintained cemetery on the main road north out of Trincomalee provides a reminder of times past when the World was a war
Very peaceful place. Very well taken care of. Stopped by here on the way back from a trip. Walked around and showed respect to those who gave the ultimate sacrifice.
This is beautifully kept. The caretaker is very knowledgeable and will show people round, answering any questions.

I couldn't go inside, but very keen to go and have a look of the peaceful RIP place, may visit soon after get to know the procedure. i was able to view and observe from out side only. Recommend tourist to vist this memorial place.

The caretaker of this peaceful cemetery is devoted to keeping it perfect and has a great knowledge of all those remembered here. He is keen to escort you round and tell you about each grave. It was close to our hotel and we were pleased to have found it by chance.

We passed this lovely cemetery on our way to Trincomalee airport and, although there was no time to stop, we could see that it was beautifully looked after.  Our driver told us that there were German as well as British and Allied military buried there, and we were very pleased to hear that.

We paused for a few minutes on our busy tour of Sri Lanka when we found ourselves by the Trincomalee War Graves. The peaceful setting and beautifully kept grounds provided a moment of quiet reflection. Each grave tells a small story - a young man (mostly) whose life was brought to an early end on a during or soon after the second world war. I counted men more than twenty ships names, and all the British armed services were represented. The war dead of other nations are also buried here. t's a beautiful place I'm glad we went.
Very well kept war cemetery. Humbling to see how many people from a wide age group (as young as in their late teens / early twenties), representing so many nationalities have died for our freedom.
So many Tamils laid to rest here after civil war in country. Sad to see so many graves of children.i felt quite saddened by it all !!
Peaceful and well kept oasis on the road between Upaveli and Nilaveli. Apparently the caretaker is very knowledgable, but the workers sitting around when I visited were not particularly helpful.

One of Trinco's great attractions, with great historical and cultural value. This place is immaculate and a pleasure to the eye. The lawns are manicured daily and the vicinity is properly maintained throughout the year. Highly recommended tourist attraction!

We stopped in front of this War Cemetery - surrounded by a low wall and gated.  It looks like it is from another world when you are in this part of Sri Lanka.  Exceptionally well maintained but totally disconnected from the true Sri Lanka

The British war cemetery in Trincomalee has tombs of British army,navy and airforce officers who died in Sri Lanka between 1939 and 1945 (The year the country won freedom from the British) It's a heart opening place where you see so many young officers had given life for a pointless war and buried in a country so far away from their homeland.
This is the best kept cemetery in Sri Lanka, was very moving . The men who tough for the world were very young. So sad yet proud
It is beautifully maintained, and the curator has all sorts of interesting information to hand out to visitors.

Maintained immaculately by what appears to be a local and British Trust , this is a poignant reminder of how much suffering and sadness has been seen by this region from war and conflict in it's recent history. A must visit. Also check out the graves of the Indian labourer and Pakistani war veterans alongside their English and other multinational victims of WW 2 all maintained by a local keeper.

A beautifully maintained British War Cemetery which is an unusual sight in Sri Lanka going by the other ordinary cemeteries found in the country  . It stands as a permanent monument to remind us of all the British Soldiers who laid down their lives whilst based in Ceylon as it was then known during World War2.
Such a beautiful, sad, and respectful place which is immaculately kept by the Sri Lankans. Well worth a visit to pay your respects to the fallen of WW2 who lost their lives around the Indian Ocean.

Beautifully and respectfully tended, it is an oasis of silence and spirituality. Due to some dramatic bombardment, doctors, nurses, civilians and soldiers, many of them in their early twenties, passed away in this region in the very last days of WWII. Christians, Muslims, Hindus and Buddhists are resting side by side. Epigraphs written by parents or young spouses pay honor to the loved ones sacrificed to the absurdity of war, moving words trying to make sense of something that cannot have sense. God bless all of them.
It is near the tricomali also known as Trinco fort.no one was there to explain us .Hence no more information .
I think you'd need a lot of time to want to tour this site, but we did stop the car and took a photo as we passed by. It is a pretty place

This cemetery was unknown to our driver and he was grateful that we had decided to stop here.  We had not realised how heavily this area of Sri Lanka had suffered in the WW2 and walked around the well kept cemetery with the caretaker who had taken on the job from his father and who will pass the job on to his son.   The caretaker was very proud to show us old pictures of his family with royalty. Entrance is free but expect to reward the caretaker with a tip!
This War Heros Cemetry was within walking distance from the Chaaya Blu hotel .It is immaculately kept and was from 1939 to 1945 war.Very moving ,reminded me of the war cemeteries in France.
This is a well maintained place related to WW2. The story behind this place is sad. We should protect his place.

We felt it only right whilst in the area to pay a short visit to the commonwealth war cemetery. Wonderfully kept place and a very moving spot in Trinco. Very peaceful and humbling. A must visit to pay my respect to the fallen.

We were surprised to see this as the number 1 thing to do and it was only a short walk from our hotel. The cemetery is small but well maintained and you should visit if you are staying nearby or driving past. At the going down of the sun, And in the morning, We will remember them.

Stopped as  a extra stop. Overseas war casultes buried here from nz , au and us. Found the grounds keeper who was rd generation looking after the cemetary. He was very knowlegable and shoed us the 4 graves of the nzed. Very moving

As the title says it is a relatively modest but very well maintained cemetery. Right on the main road heading north out of Trincomalee, easy walking distance from the main cluster of tourist resorts. We spend 20 minutes there and that was enough to look over each headstone - my father was based in Trincomalee during WWII so he had a few old colleagues buried there
Beautifully kept as are all of the War Graves.  On a busy road but so peaceful.  Well worth stopping for a few moments.
The cemetery is a very fitting tribute to the fallen. It is well maintained and cared for by the staff.
Very well kept cemetery with several hundred Graves. A lot of them are from after the conclusion of the 2nd world war. Worth a visit if passing.

We visited this WW2 war cemetery and were impressed by the care and attention lavished on the gravestones and surrounding garden. Sobering to read the names and ages on the stones from all over the Commonwealth who gave their all for our future. A credit to the custodian and his parents before him for such a tranquil  place.
Had a glance. Was built between 1959-1945. Love how they still keep it. Emphasizes the colonial era in Sri Lankan history. its on the way to Nilaweli. Don't forget to stop & have a look.

This is a British military cemetery in Trincomalee, Sri Lanka, for soldiers of the British Empire who were killed or died during World War II. The cemetery is located on the Trincomalee–Nilaveli Road. It is one of the six Commonwealth war cemeteries in Sri Lanka, and maintained by Sri Lankan Ministry of Defense on behalf of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission.
Very well maintained.  Worth visiting, but there is also one in Kandy which is very similar.  You can get coconut drink outside... they add sugar and lime to it.

Maintain by the Navy. You can see how the Trinco fort was built in ancient SL. Also about the boats ships and the harbor. How our forces destroy LTTE boats. Great for young once and the students. Nominal fee has to be paid.
Visited for a short while on the way Nilaveli. Nicely kept and peacefull. Do not read the grave stones unless you want to break your heart thinking how young they were..
A beautiful spot in the hustle and bussel of the area, we were welcomed and given a tour and history lesson a must if you are in the area
This is an interesting place for British travelers.On the way to Nilaveli it is worth a brake for 20 minutes to honor all these young people who died for their country.Very well maintained.

A well maintained peaceful and lovely cemetery. Worth a visit. Interestingly, the gravestones are separated into sections - Christian, Hindu, Muslim and one lonely little stone for an unknown Burmese soldier.

Beautifully maintained and very calm and peaceful.  A real credit to the caretaker who showed us around and then told us that his father had done this job before and that his son would take over from him.
It is an important place to see in Trincomalee that many locals are not aware of. It's well maintained and a peaceful cemetery on the main road to Nilaveli from Trinco town.
Excellently kept by the Custodian.  He is a wealth of knowledge and will be pleased to give you some of the background to the cemetery.

Beautifully kept. Current caretaker is son of former caretaker. Family tradition and commitment. Within easy walking distance of the Chaaya Blu. They were all so young - 364 brave souls gave their today for our tomorrow.

The cemetery is beautifully maintained and the custodian has a detailed knowledge of the background of all those  are buried there. It was touching to see that in death, all were equal and that graves were not arranged according to rank, race or religion.

Our brief visit to Trincomalee War Cemetery was very well impressed with the level the cemetery was kept all these years.  Viewing the soldiers and the years associated to their history according to the head stones was amazed the very young age they were.  The peacefulness of the place had most of us spent longer time than we intended.  The cemetery keeper was very attentive to his duty and took great pride in maintaining the ground.

We have visited many commonwealth war cemeteries. Without doubt the standard of maintenance here is the finest we have seen and it does  the present and past caretakers great credit. The flower and shrub displays were beautiful.
This was a very well maintained War Cemetery.  Although located alongside the main road it was a very peaceful place.

The Trincomalee War Cemetery is the second Commonwealth War Graves Commission cemetery I have visited. The other was in Berlin, where I visited my uncle's grave. The Trincomalee War Cemetery is lovingly tended and we met the caretaker who came out and chatted to us and showed us around. He has a great knowledge of the graves and took the job over from his father when he retired. It is good to know that our war heroes are treated with such respect and kindness even though their remains are far from home.The quotes on the headstones from family are particularly poignant. I recommend a visit, if only to bring home the futility of war.

This is a small war cemetery on the road to Nilaveli Beach it is immaculately maintained the green lawns kept trim by the small team of gardeners and all the headstones are in very good condition a War cemetery kept respectfully by the locals; worth a visit on your way to the nearby temple or beach.

The above are the feelings experienced when visiting any of the fine gardens of remembrance maintained by the commonwealth war graves commission, Trincomalee is no exception, albeit smaller than many this does not diminish the stature of those who gave their all and for whom this is their resting place,the garden is well maintained and the attendants are only too willing to share their pride and documentation of the gardens history.It is only fitting that we are able to remember in respectful surroundings

Palto had once said " Only the dead see the end of a war " , Probably the uniform serenity in the manner the tombstones are laid, adds the chill to the valour of those laid to rest. Probably a reminder that mother earth is one home backyard  to us all . Death during a war , seems like a visa to be buried in the soil of another country and also the result of the war mongers of yesteryear who sat on the realms of power and make wrong decisions, that took the lives of many.  - Remember the song "Where have all the Flowers Gone", and then remember the part " When will they ever learn " It still valid for today.

A poignant memorial to those young soldiers who fell to the enemy during WWII. Reading a few tombstones one is saddened that some kids hardly 18 years old who had joined the forces, are buried thousands of miles away from their homelands.
Worth visiting this place. Well maintained. Military service personnel who sacrificed their lives are resting here.
This is a well kept reminder of the tragedy when war ships were bombed during the 2nd World war well kept by a Sri Lankan family.
Worth a visit to this place and pay our respect to the once who have sacrificed their lives during World War
Immaculate condition and looked after by the same family since 1945.  They give you an article to read which tells about the role of Ceylon during World War 2

The cemetery is very well maintained and the guardian is very proud to show you around. His father was the guardian of the cemetery and they have very nice picture of Princess Ann, visiting the place in 1992.
Nothing much to see unless you´re interested in World War II and know the history. Please take a historical guide with you.
Beautiful and moving place. Well kept and worth a visit, good groundsman who explained lots to us.  Not a big place so good for a quick visit

Gem of a place located on Nilaveli Road . Not too difficult to find . No entrance fee. Well maintained . Serene place for those departed souls. Was lucky enough to meet the head Gardner who gave us a chapter out of our history book . Simply remarkable attention to detail . A must visit for anyone who comes to Trinco

As expected a well kept cemetery. We were welcomed by the caretaker who takes great pride in his work and wanted to make sure everybody understood the history behind this cemetery. Some of the headstones show damage from the recent civil unrest whilst others have been recently replaced. A moving reminder to previous conflicts and well worth visiting for a few minutes to remember those who died in a distant land.
lovely person and very helpful that showed us round, well kept , they have a visitors book to sign and you can spend as long or as little time that you would like to there.
Small, very clean and well maintained, in a pretty green hill, this cemetery is like a jump in the past!

The gentleman who cared for this cemetery was a proud man who showed us photographs of when his father was in charge and Princess Ann visited and planted a tree. The cemetery is beautifully kept and there are some very interesting graves to see. The tree Princess Ann planted is quite large now.
A nice cemetery to have a walk around. People are there to give you more information about the cemetery if you want it, we said no and they didn't keep pushing the fact.
Credit to the Commonwealth War Graves Commission. A tranquil and fitting memorial to those young men who rest here.

This Second World War cemetery is relatively small in comparison to the other in Asia.  However it is very well maintained and give a serene atmosphere throughout.  Our group which composed of some British and Australian spent quite sometime in the cemetery observing the name, age, and year on the head stones.  We were curious that some of the dates on the head stones were actually after end of the war.  No one was able to explain to us on this mystery.

This Commonwealth cemetery does not cover a large area, so we can be thankful the losses while still sad for all, were not great in numbers, around 600 killed during world war 2. It has the same aura as any well maintained war cemetery and gravestones are cause for reflection, thanks and respect.

This small but beautifully maintained cemetery has so many different cultures and types of headstones. I visited cause my brother and father are huge history buffs and I  was shown 4 Canadian grave sites. I will now get them to find out mor about Sri Lanka's role in WWII.
I visited because a great uncle is buried there , but a great historic site to see , beautifully maintained and beautiful to see , interesting to read some of the headstones , tells a real story .

Trincomalee War Cemetery is another beautiful example of a well kept memorial to the men and women who died during the Second World War. The site is close to the main road but as soon as you enter the grounds you are surrounded by calm. An essential opportunity to stop and reflect....
It is quite a peaceful place. The gardens are nicely maintained. The sunset from there was worth a capture.

This was a delight,so beautifully kept and tended. the gentleman showing us around was very gentle and Respectful, showing us photos of his Father in situ when HRH the Princess Anne visited and planted a tree ,he showed great pride in his work and told us that HIs son was being trained to take the reigns when he retired a wonderful memory thank you.
Fully worth the time spent if you're already in Trinco. Very pleasant location and maintained in perfect condition.

This was our 2nd visit to this Cemetery and like all the war cemeteries we have visited is kept in beautiful condition it's so peaceful. The person who looks after it takes his responsibility with great pride, having met his father before I can understand how important this job is to him. He is very knowledgeable and helpful even telling a group of locals to be quiet and  more respectful. Those  young men and women of many nationalities gave their lives for us and we should be so grateful to them for the freedom we have today.
The guy who looked after it was so nice ,i took flowers and laid them on the cross ,it was kept immaculate ,very peaceful .

Was on a group tour.  When offered the opportunity to stop and look, 6 of us grabbed the chance and got off the bus, and went over.  Welcomed by the keeper who is extremely knowledgeable of who is there.  He took over after his father retired.  They being the only two who have maintained these grounds beautifully.  He told  us that there were 303 graves of which 5 are New Zealanders. He could lead us directly to them.  It is a peaceful calm place and we are grateful that we were able to photograph the headstones. We plan to make these available on the web for all.

Beautifully kept, small commonwealth war cemetery. The young age of the men who sacrificed their life's  is heartbreaking. As a commonwealth cemetery many nationalities are remembered here, but mainly British Royal and Merchant mariners.

this modern cemetary is full of  caracter. Very well maintained, we were very friendly welcomed and could make pictures everywhere we wanted, in a respectful way. Good place for reflections about the very hard time people had to survive, especially in this area. It was a surprise to discover such a peaceful place outsite Trinco. Worth visiting.

It is a beautiful cemetery. In fact, it is THE prettiest I have seen in Sri Lanka. We looked at it while being in the vehicle right outside the cemetery and since it was quite hot at that time, we did not go in. So I can't say much.

The 1939-1945 War Cemetry not only honours the fallen, but is a tribute to the custodians who maintain and care for it.  It's set a bit out of town, but that only adds to the surroundings. All the graves are beautifully maintained, with bright coloured plants to add just that bit of brightness.  The custodians must also be credited with holding an extensive range of records relating both the fallen who are buried here and the bombing of Trincomalee. We would rate this Commonwealth War Cemetry with a 10/10 to match Kandy (Sri Lanka) and Adelaide River (Northern Territory, Australia)

Having stayed on Sober island I felt my visit to Trinco would be incomplete if I did not visit the Trinco War cemetery. It was a well kept place and interesting to wander around reading the epitahs and names of those who had laid down their lives .

went here whilst holidaying in trinco in august so beautifully  kept peaceful tranquil it was a scorching day but the watering system was in place The guy who looks after it told us that the British government helps to pay for its upkeep what a n appropriate  place to remember all the lives which  were lost
The headstones of the fallen of WW2 from many countries are set in this immaculately kept cemetery. A tribute to the gardeners who keep it in such beautiful condition.
This cemetery is very well maintained. It is a very interesting place, but has a conflicting history.

This is not a large war cemetery but it is full of history and is the resting place of many servicemen from around the world.  The grounds keeper does an amazing job of keeping this place in such beautiful condition. He takes pride in his work and shows the servicemen the respect they are due.  Worth a look.

A visit to the Commonwealth Cemetery is a must do when visiting Trinco. It is not only Australian, New Zealanders and Brits laid to rest in this green and perfectly kept oasis. The Dutch, French, Indian and a few other warriors and nurses are laid to rest in the tribute to the fallen. It's about fifteen minutes drive form the city, on the way to Nilaveli. The guardian is second generation of this family to preserve this war memorial, and will inform and guide with respect to any graves you are interested in. I found a visit here very moving, not only for the tragic loss, but for the care that this cemetery is watched over.
A lovely quiet oasis in a mad world to reflect on the lives lost . The cemetery is so well looked after.

This cemetery is a credit to the man who maintains it. His father had that task before him and such is his dedication that he knows the name of every person interred there and the location of each grave. Most of the soldiers were killed by bombing of ships in the Trincomalee harbour which is the fifth largest natural harbour in the world. There were even two Australians buried there. It was a moving experience to visit and stroll through the cemetery.
Well worth  a visit if local history is of interest. The cemetary is very well maintained. and not too far to travel too. If interested in details allow a bit of time to browse through the cemetary.

It was very hot and sunny, with no shade, but we spent quite a long time here.  Like all Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemeteries, it was beautifully maintained, and like several graveyards we visited in Sri Lanka, it had been maintained by one family for many years.  It was moving to see (mainly) Naval personnel from all over the Commonwealth and of all ranks and religions given equally beautiful headstones.  The Custodian was rightly proud of it, and we were glad we gave up the time to remember those who were largely bombed in ships in the harbour and in shore establishments in Sri Lanka.  (We had to look up the various ships, despite being keen Naval history buffs - it was a part of the war not much written about).
Beautifully kept tribute to those who gave the ultimate sacrifice. Needs a dedicated parking area to attract more visitors - very hard to safely pull off the road.

This Commonwealth War Graves Commission site is know locally as the 'British Cemetery'.  Two to three hundred rupee tuk tuk ride from town, or a 900 local bus.  You are met by a second generation curator who will escort you   In this beautiful spot there are 362 graves of which two are Australian,  328 British, and a whole mixture of other fairs and nationalities, even the Indian labourers, mostly with only one anglicised name, are even remembered here. It was set up in 1947' and even has graves for people who dies aft the 39-45 war.   During the civil war there was an engagement between the SLArmy helicopters and the LTTE (Tamil tigers) which damaged 22 of the headstones, the ones that were not replaced the damage can still be seen. (Eg. Scrivener)    Some graves had the usual religions and like epitaph engraved but I loved wasa serjeant(sic) G.A.Kyle whose epitaph was 'curry anything'.

Amazing to see the graves so well maintained after all these years. In absolute pristine condition. Definitely worth a visit. The chap running the show is part of a family who have looked after the site since the world war - nice guy.
everything is like what it was many years ago now it is really excellent specially after the 30 year war

This oasis of green and calm on the edge of Trinco is just so very moving. The headstones chart the loss of life of mainly naval personnel and airmen who came under tremendous attack during the war and some died well after the war was won and are buried here too. The Gardener will take you around and give you some information to read, and some of the headstones have been bullet holed in the latest Civil war so they are being replaced. The Jewish, Moslem and Christian faiths are represented and Kiwis, Aussies, Brits, Dutch, Malay, Indian and Sri Lankans are all buried together
Peaceful, respectful place. Such young men dying makes one weep. It was a moving tribute to soldiers everywhere.

Whilst one of the best maintained war cemetaries in Sri Lanka, I am not sure if the existence of the Trincomalee war cemetary is known to many. It certainly is not listed in any of the tourist maps as a place to visit. And fully worth a visit it is, especially if you are a war historian or someone who's family or country has been touched by the second world war. This is primarily a British war cemetary and maintained (beautifully I must say) from a grant from England. You are not allowed to film or take photos here, but just a stroll amongst the tombstones of the fallen, is a very poignant and sobering experience.

The WWII cemetery is beautifully kept and serves as a fitting memorial to those who lost their lives in the Second World War. The guardian is extremely helpful and treats the place as though it was his own. He took over the job from his father. Most of the British dead were in the Navy and with them lie friends from India, Canada and Sri Lanka.
